headline: Nicolle Wallace Calls on Her Former Boss, George W. Bush, to Denounce Trump
abstract: Ms. Wallace, who served as the communications director in the Bush White House, made the appeal on her MSNBC program.
lead_paragraph: Nicolle Wallace, who was a White House communications director in George W. Bush’s administration, called on Friday for Mr. Bush to have a late-hour “change of heart” and speak out against former President Donald J. Trump.
snippet: Ms. Wallace, who served as the communications director in the Bush White House, made the appeal on her MSNBC program.

headline: As Election Nears, Republicans Blame Child’s Rape on Immigration Crisis
abstract: Wilson Castillo Diaz was arrested in New York in connection with the rape of a 5-year-old girl. On Friday, local Republicans blamed Democratic immigration policies.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island man who was charged with raping a 5-year-old girl last month was in the country illegally, the police said Friday as local Republican officials sought to connect the disturbing case to the bitter debate over immigration just days before the presidential vote.
snippet: Wilson Castillo Diaz was arrested in New York in connection with the rape of a 5-year-old girl. On Friday, local Republicans blamed Democratic immigration policies.

headline: Uncertainty Reigns in Nevada With Rise of Nonpartisan Voters
abstract: With early voting coming to a close, Donald Trump and Kamala Harris must now ensure their respective bases show up on Election Day, while chasing down those whose choice is less clear.
lead_paragraph: As early voting came to a close in Nevada, many of the state’s most veteran pollsters, pundits and political operatives — no strangers to close elections and their accompanying jitters — are finding it uniquely difficult to predict what happens next.
snippet: With early voting coming to a close, Donald Trump and Kamala Harris must now ensure their respective bases show up on Election Day, while chasing down those whose choice is less clear.

headline: Judge Allows Unusual G.O.P. Strategy to Pump Money Into Senate Races
abstract: Democrats had claimed that the advertising strategy may have violated federal election laws establishing strict limits on spending by national party committees to aid individual candidates.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled on Friday that Senate Republicans may continue to pump tens of millions of dollars into key swing state races in the final days of the 2024 campaign by employing an unusual advertising strategy that Democrats had claimed was potentially illegal.
snippet: Democrats had claimed that the advertising strategy may have violated federal election laws establishing strict limits on spending by national party committees to aid individual candidates.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 2, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the Tony Award winner Brandon Uranowitz misspelled the name of a play. It is “Leopoldstadt,” not “Leopoldstat.
snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 2, 2024.

headline: No, vote spikes on election night do not indicate voter fraud.
abstract: The false claim, which has circulated in recent elections, is based on a misunderstanding of how votes are collected and reported.
lead_paragraph: Vote totals appear to suddenly surge on election night, sometimes benefiting just one candidate. Some people on social media have falsely claimed that this proves fraudulent votes were counted.
snippet: The false claim, which has circulated in recent elections, is based on a misunderstanding of how votes are collected and reported.

headline: Band Aids
abstract: Blake Slonecker delivers a cutting-edge Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Just a few tricky word usages in the clues are often all it takes to elevate the difficulty of a grid. I think that’s the case with today’s themeless puzzle, Blake Slonecker’s third Saturday crossword for The New York Times. None of the slightly skewed verbiage misdirected me, but I did draw a blank several times before getting enough letters from crossing entries to make deductions, and those letters built fairly slowly.
snippet: Blake Slonecker delivers a cutting-edge Saturday puzzle.

headline: Federal Jury Finds Ex-Officer Guilty of Violating Breonna Taylor’s Rights
abstract: The former detective fired 10 shots through Ms. Taylor’s apartment in a raid in 2020 that set off a wave of protests across the country.
lead_paragraph: The former police detective who fired 10 shots through Breonna Taylor’s apartment in a deadly raid in Louisville, Ky., in 2020 was found guilty on Friday night of violating her civil rights by using excessive force.
snippet: The former detective fired 10 shots through Ms. Taylor’s apartment in a raid in 2020 that set off a wave of protests across the country.

headline: Judge Finds Pennsylvania County Short of Ballots and Extends Early-Voting Hours
abstract: A state judge in Erie County, Pa., found that thousands of voters may not have received their ballots in time for the election on Tuesday, ordering the county to remedy the issue.
lead_paragraph: A state judge in Pennsylvania has found that a mail-ballot vendor contracted by the Erie County Board of Elections failed to meet demand and that 13,000 to 17,000 Erie County voters may not have received their ballots in time for the election on Tuesday.
snippet: A state judge in Erie County, Pa., found that thousands of voters may not have received their ballots in time for the election on Tuesday, ordering the county to remedy the issue.

headline: To Join This Club, a Member Must Die. And You Must Adore Verdi.
abstract: Based in Parma, Club dei 27 is so exclusive that it’s given rise to all sorts of myths. But it’s really about venerating the famous opera composer born near the Italian city.
lead_paragraph: They did not sing “Happy Birthday.” At least, not at first.
snippet: Based in Parma, Club dei 27 is so exclusive that it’s given rise to all sorts of myths. But it’s really about venerating the famous opera composer born near the Italian city.

headline: Can Iran and Israel Find a New Equilibrium?
abstract: Even with peace talks underway, the region is far from stable.
lead_paragraph: The Middle East is still in a state of volatile uncertainty after the latest exchange of missiles between Israel and Iran.
snippet: Even with peace talks underway, the region is far from stable.

headline: Quote of the Day: U.C.L.A. Football Travel This Season (In Miles)
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We fly Southwest a lot, so you have a 310-pound lineman in a middle seat with two women because we’re in boarding group C.”
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 2, 2024.

headline: Scenes of Trench Warfare in the Age of Drones
abstract: At a critical battlefield in eastern Ukraine, advanced technology is shaping battles that resemble the wars of older eras. When drones are watching, assaults become violent sprints.
lead_paragraph: Five Russian soldiers, armed with rifles and grenades, crawled from their trenches into a low-lying ravine, ready to assault the Ukrainian position. At least one of them heard a hornet-like hum and looked up, into the lens of a drone looming above them, and realized that they had been detected.
snippet: At a critical battlefield in eastern Ukraine, advanced technology is shaping battles that resemble the wars of older eras. When drones are watching, assaults become violent sprints.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,233
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 3, 2024.

headline: They Don’t Care About the Marathon. They Just Want to Cross the Street.
abstract: In a city where grousing about nearly anything is fair game, some people see the race more as an inconvenience than as a festive occasion.
lead_paragraph: To many New Yorkers, the first Sunday in November means a chance to watch runners from all over the world chase their dreams in the New York City Marathon.
snippet: In a city where grousing about nearly anything is fair game, some people see the race more as an inconvenience than as a festive occasion.

headline: The G.O.P. Gained Ground in New York in 2022. Can Democrats Recover?
abstract: Democrats still hold supermajorities in both chambers of the State Legislature, but Republicans are hoping to keep the momentum from the 2022 midterms.
lead_paragraph: There are few places in America that are bluer than the State Capitol in Albany, N.Y., where Democrats have held supermajorities in both houses of the Legislature, as well as the governor’s mansion, since 2018.
snippet: Democrats still hold supermajorities in both chambers of the State Legislature, but Republicans are hoping to keep the momentum from the 2022 midterms.

headline: How a Pizzeria Owner With a Million Fans on Instagram Spends His Sundays
abstract: Frank Kabatas serves slices to his hungry customers at East Village Pizza while posting videos for his insatiable audience of 1.7 million followers on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: On his second day in New York, Frank Kabatas stepped into East Village Pizza for the first time. As a child in Turkey, he’d eaten plenty of pide — a cheesy flatbread cousin of pizza — but he’d never been able to afford a proper slice. In 1997, when he was 23, he got a green card and decided to join his brother Mel in New York. Mel was working at the pizzeria, and he served Frank his first plain cheese slice.
snippet: Frank Kabatas serves slices to his hungry customers at East Village Pizza while posting videos for his insatiable audience of 1.7 million followers on Instagram.

headline: Trump Bashes Arab Americans. Here’s Why Some Like Him Anyway.
abstract: In a diverse enclave on Staten Island, some business owners say former President Donald J. Trump’s racist rhetoric and anti-Muslim policies are troubling but not disqualifying.
lead_paragraph: To better understand Donald Trump’s surging appeal among immigrant voters a friend suggested that I visit a particular corner of Staten Island, where an astonishingly diverse population, clustered around a set of minority-owned businesses, has recently emerged on a stretch of Hylan Boulevard.
snippet: In a diverse enclave on Staten Island, some business owners say former President Donald J. Trump’s racist rhetoric and anti-Muslim policies are troubling but not disqualifying.

headline: Kay Koplovitz Wants to See More Entrepreneurs Who Look Like Her
abstract: Once the most powerful woman in television, the founder of Springboard has spent the past 20 years identifying and funding female-led start-ups.
lead_paragraph: Kay Koplovitz still remembers her first negotiation. Her family was moving from one suburb of Milwaukee to another in the middle of the school year, and she wanted to finish kindergarten with her class. To cover the bus fare back to her old neighborhood, she persuaded her father to raise her allowance. “I sort of felt, well, my first one was successful,” she now says of the deal. “Why wouldn’t all the rest of them be?”
snippet: Once the most powerful woman in television, the founder of Springboard has spent the past 20 years identifying and funding female-led start-ups.

headline: The Coming of the ‘Messiah’: How Handel’s Masterpiece Was Born
abstract: John Adams reviews “Every Valley,” Charles King’s new book about the artistic, social and political forces surrounding one of the greatest pieces of music ever created.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Handel’s head is more full of Maggots than ever. … I could tell you more … but it grows late & I must defer the rest until I write next; by which time, I doubt not, more new ones will breed in his Brain.”
snippet: John Adams reviews “Every Valley,” Charles King’s new book about the artistic, social and political forces surrounding one of the greatest pieces of music ever created.

headline: Professors Are Uniquely Powerful. That May Be Changing.
abstract: Faculty members are used to sharing power with presidents and trustees to run universities. But some presidents and lawmakers have made moves to reduce their say.
lead_paragraph: Ilya Nemenman, an Emory University physics professor, seethed as summer break neared its end.
snippet: Faculty members are used to sharing power with presidents and trustees to run universities. But some presidents and lawmakers have made moves to reduce their say.

headline: Russia Showers Cash on Men Enlisting in Ukraine War, Bringing Prosperity to Some Towns
abstract: With fewer men willing to fight, Russia is focusing on cash incentives for those who sign up, seeking to avoid an unpopular draft while still increasing the ranks of soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Expensive new cars and motorcycles crowd the streets. Apartment prices have more than doubled. And once-strapped residents are suddenly seen wearing fur coats and carrying ostentatiously overflowing grocery bags.
snippet: With fewer men willing to fight, Russia is focusing on cash incentives for those who sign up, seeking to avoid an unpopular draft while still increasing the ranks of soldiers.

headline: A Whisperer to the Stars on the Middle East Conflict
abstract: Many in Hollywood have struggled to navigate how to talk about their support for Israel on social media. Some of them have turned to Hen Mazzig for advice.
lead_paragraph: The actress Debra Messing had a question: How do you share commentary about the Israel-Hamas conflict online in ways that will best influence others?
snippet: Many in Hollywood have struggled to navigate how to talk about their support for Israel on social media. Some of them have turned to Hen Mazzig for advice.

headline: Donald Trump’s 2024 in Pictures
abstract: A historic conviction. A sudden new opponent. Gunfire in Butler. Donald Trump’s year was unlike that of any presidential candidate in political history.
snippet: A historic conviction. A sudden new opponent. Gunfire in Butler. Donald Trump’s year was unlike that of any presidential candidate in political history.

headline: Four Must-See Parks This Fall Herald a New Golden Age
abstract: Decades of planning and restoration come to fruition at Seattle’s Waterfront Park, a new Central Park rink and pool, the grounds of Olana, and Longwood Gardens in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: The greening of Seattle’s commercial waterfront could not happen until a blighting highway was ripped down and a crumbling sea wall replaced.
snippet: Decades of planning and restoration come to fruition at Seattle’s Waterfront Park, a new Central Park rink and pool, the grounds of Olana, and Longwood Gardens in Pennsylvania.

headline: The Writing Tool That Mark Twain, Agatha Christie and James Joyce All Swore By
abstract: A new history by Roland Allen uncovers the wealth of ideas and invention hidden in the notebooks of literary luminaries.
lead_paragraph: A notebook is a record of both solitude and connection. It’s a place for making real the quiet, flickering thoughts that otherwise might pass unnoticed, where words and sketches can stumble and fail. In a notebook, failure is less consequential because it’s not failure at all; it’s a necessary part of the messiness of exploration, of letting the unknown and the uncertain find form.
snippet: A new history by Roland Allen uncovers the wealth of ideas and invention hidden in the notebooks of literary luminaries.

headline: At 70, a Marathoner Looks Back
abstract: After a lifetime of running, a writer reflects on why he’s coming back for one last race.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been training to run the New York City Marathon on Sunday. At age 70, even in the best conditions, it would be a slog over 26.2 miles, longer than five hours. That is less a time for a race than a recipe for short ribs.
snippet: After a lifetime of running, a writer reflects on why he’s coming back for one last race.

headline: Wendi McLendon-Covey Is No Longer a Brunch Person
abstract: “I don’t know how to have one mimosa,” said the actress, one of the stars of the new sitcom “St. Denis Medical.” Now she’s a fan of “dunch.”
lead_paragraph: If Wendi McLendon-Covey had her druthers, she and her husband, Greg Covey, would see every band that rolled into Los Angeles.
snippet: “I don’t know how to have one mimosa,” said the actress, one of the stars of the new sitcom “St. Denis Medical.” Now she’s a fan of “dunch.”

headline: It Started With a Family Tree. It Became ‘a Memorial to Everything.’
abstract: A search for his origins led Archie Moore to the farthest corners of Australia’s history and the Golden Lion prize at the Venice Biennale.
lead_paragraph: At the center of Archie Moore’s “Kith and Kin,” installed in the Australian pavilion at this year’s Venice Biennale, a large tabletop hovers above an inky reflecting pool. The table holds stacks of paper, each pile an official record of an Indigenous Australian’s death in custody since 1991. On the pavilion’s black walls, a chalk drawing traces a genealogical map.
snippet: A search for his origins led Archie Moore to the farthest corners of Australia’s history and the Golden Lion prize at the Venice Biennale.

headline: What Happens to All Your Compost? Meet the Person Who Handles It.
abstract: For the latest episode of “On the Job,” Priya Krishna spent a night picking up compost with Paul Campbell, who removes thousands of pounds of food waste from New York businesses.
lead_paragraph: For 18 years, Paul Campbell has been lugging 300-pound bins filled with watermelon rinds, coconut shells and other compost onto a truck in the dead of the night. As a sanitation worker, he sees a part of New York that few ever get the chance to glimpse: its vast food waste.
snippet: For the latest episode of “On the Job,” Priya Krishna spent a night picking up compost with Paul Campbell, who removes thousands of pounds of food waste from New York businesses.

headline: In Shift From 2020, Identity Politics Loses Its Grip on the Country
abstract: There are signs that society is moving away from the progressive left’s often strict expectations about how to discuss culture and politics.
lead_paragraph: The last time Kamala Harris ran for president, during the 2020 primaries, people were losing jobs or friends because something they said or posted online came off as insensitive.
snippet: There are signs that society is moving away from the progressive left’s often strict expectations about how to discuss culture and politics.

headline: Bringing Attitude, and Exclusivity, to the World of Running Gear
abstract: Bandit wants to “evolve running,” and the apparel company will be in the spotlight during the New York City Marathon.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Ashley Ellefson, a 39-year-old operations executive, was running along Manhattan’s East River Promenade when she spotted a group of men, many of them clad in Bandit Running gear, coming toward her. They ran her off the road.
snippet: Bandit wants to “evolve running,” and the apparel company will be in the spotlight during the New York City Marathon.

headline: John Leguizamo Talked Diversity at the Emmys. He Has Ideas for Theater Too.
abstract: The actor discusses his new play, “The Other Americans,” feeling underappreciated as a dramatist, and Latino representation.
lead_paragraph: In his new play, “The Other Americans,” John Leguizamo stars as Nelson Castro, a Colombian laundromat owner in Queens whose life begins to unravel as his family struggles to, as Leguizamo puts it, “survive the American dream.”
snippet: The actor discusses his new play, “The Other Americans,” feeling underappreciated as a dramatist, and Latino representation.

headline: It’s Time to Shop for Medicare, and 2025 Brings Big Changes
abstract: A bumper crop of revisions, including a stronger drug benefit, means the plan you enrolled in for 2024 may not be the best fit next year.
lead_paragraph: Americans on Medicare will see big, and welcome, changes next year. The program’s prescription drug insurance will be much stronger — and easier to understand — as a result of the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022.
snippet: A bumper crop of revisions, including a stronger drug benefit, means the plan you enrolled in for 2024 may not be the best fit next year.

headline: Kamala Harris’s 2024 in Pictures
abstract: As the year began, few expected Kamala Harris to make a historic march toward the presidency. After a head-spinning summer, her campaign’s remarkable story awaits its conclusion.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has run a presidential campaign like no other in modern American history. Thrust unexpectedly onto the top of the ticket, she had less than four months to take on former President Donald J. Trump, who has dominated the nation’s politics for nearly a decade.
snippet: As the year began, few expected Kamala Harris to make a historic march toward the presidency. After a head-spinning summer, her campaign’s remarkable story awaits its conclusion.

headline: Stolen Packages: When You Can, and Can’t, Blame Your Landlord
abstract: Landlords are not legally required to provide delivery lockers, or concierges, if these are not already provided services in your building.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a nice rent-stabilized building in Park Slope, Brooklyn. We’ve had packages stolen for months, not to mention a few intruders, including some teenagers caught smoking marijuana in a common area. Our building has neither a doorman nor a concierge, only a front door entry code and surveillance cameras. The super refuses to get involved and tells us to call the police. We’ve notified our management company, asking them to improve security with lockers or a virtual concierge, to no avail. How can we get management to take action? Do we have any legal recourse?
snippet: Landlords are not legally required to provide delivery lockers, or concierges, if these are not already provided services in your building.

headline: How to Survive Swing State Stress: Prayer, Canvassing and Knowing When to Let Go
abstract: Georgia’s status as a battleground state is a source of pride, but also of high anxiety at the end of a grinding election.
lead_paragraph: One poll has Vice President Kamala Harris ahead in Georgia by four points, and another has former President Donald J. Trump leading by six. A couple more have the candidates effectively tied.
snippet: Georgia’s status as a battleground state is a source of pride, but also of high anxiety at the end of a grinding election.

headline: How Donald Trump Replaced ‘the Protestant Pope’
abstract: Billy Graham towered over American evangelicalism for 50 years. Now the fight is on to own his legacy.
lead_paragraph: In the final stretch of a presidential election between two candidates who don’t speak often about their personal religious beliefs, an itinerant evangelist born in 1918 has become the subject of a skirmish in the ongoing civil war over the future of evangelical Christianity in America.
snippet: Billy Graham towered over American evangelicalism for 50 years. Now the fight is on to own his legacy.

headline: Who Is Kamala Anyway?
abstract: Wesley Morris has a theory.
lead_paragraph: When Wesley Morris began watching the Democratic National Convention last August, he started to worry. Kamala was slotted to accept the nomination for president after Michelle Obama spoke. Would she be able follow an act like that?
snippet: Wesley Morris has a theory.

headline: The Biggest Question in North Carolina: Can Democrats Win?
abstract: Republicans have been quick to temper Democratic optimism in a state where rural areas, and maybe just enough suburbs and exurbs, remain reliably red.
lead_paragraph: In the western mountains, wealthy coastal towns, and urban and rural areas in between, North Carolina voters agree on this: It has been an exhausting and unsettling final stretch of the election in their state. After a devastating hurricane and a jolting political scandal, they are ready for a result.
snippet: Republicans have been quick to temper Democratic optimism in a state where rural areas, and maybe just enough suburbs and exurbs, remain reliably red.

headline: Squirrels, Soda and Tractors: 12 Emergencies You Never Thought About but Election Officials Are Prepared For
abstract: Local election workers share how they would respond to a range of scenarios, using a 52-card game.
lead_paragraph: Local election workers share how they would respond to a range of scenarios, using a 52-card game.
snippet: Local election workers share how they would respond to a range of scenarios, using a 52-card game.

headline: How Missile Defense Works (and Why It Fails)
abstract: Iran fired two of the largest barrages of ballistic missiles ever at Israel this year. Even the world’s best defenses don’t always stop them.
lead_paragraph: Iran fired two of the largest barrages of ballistic missiles ever at Israel this year. Even the world’s best defenses don’t always stop them.
snippet: Iran fired two of the largest barrages of ballistic missiles ever at Israel this year. Even the world’s best defenses don’t always stop them.

headline: 3 Terrific Specials to Distract You From the News
abstract: Tom Papa, James Adomian and Emily Catalano take very different, very funny approaches in their new hours.
lead_paragraph: (Stream it on Netflix)
snippet: Tom Papa, James Adomian and Emily Catalano take very different, very funny approaches in their new hours.

headline: Behind a Wall of Trees, Archaeologists Discover a Maya City
abstract: A city with temple pyramids not far from the road and a site with a Maya complex built alongside a sinkhole lend to evidence that the Maya civilization was even more sprawling than known.
lead_paragraph: East of the town of Dos Lagunas, past the major highway cutting through Mexico’s south, the forest rises up in a dense wall of grasping roots, spindly branches and veils of brown and green.
snippet: A city with temple pyramids not far from the road and a site with a Maya complex built alongside a sinkhole lend to evidence that the Maya civilization was even more sprawling than known.

headline: Our Photographers’ Favorite Campaign Trail Photos
abstract: How did they get those photos? Doug Mills, who has been photographing former President Donald J. Trump for The New York Times, and Erin Schaff, who has been photographing Vice President Kamala Harris, tell the stories behind their favorite photos of the candidates.
lead_paragraph: How did they get those photos? Doug Mills, who has been photographing former President Donald J. Trump for The New York Times, and Erin Schaff, who has been photographing Vice President Kamala Harris, tell the stories behind their favorite photos of the candidates.
snippet: How did they get those photos? Doug Mills, who has been photographing former President Donald J. Trump for The New York Times, and Erin Schaff, who has been photographing Vice President Kamala Harris, tell the stories behind their favorite photos ...

headline: Murders Surged in the Pandemic. Now in Many Cities That Surge Is Gone.
abstract: A huge drop in 2023 has been followed by an even greater improvement so far this year.
lead_paragraph: Murders declined at a remarkable rate in America in 2023, with official statistics showing the largest one-year drop in more than half a century. Even more remarkable: This year looks on track for an even greater improvement.
snippet: A huge drop in 2023 has been followed by an even greater improvement so far this year.

headline: How Will White Women Vote? It’s a Question With a Fraught History.
abstract: White and Black women have joined together to power progressive causes — from abolition to civil rights — but it’s a tenuous alliance.
lead_paragraph: With a closely contested election just days away, much attention has been paid in recent weeks to whether enough Black men are willing to vote for a Black woman for president. The argument goes that Black men may be the obstacle to Kamala Harris’s defeating Donald Trump — and becoming the first female president. In a video that went viral, former President Barack Obama chided Black men for maybe not wanting to support Harris because she’s a woman; some polling shows her Black-male support slipping. News networks devoted numerous segments to pundits’ raising the alarm about the ambivalence of some Black men to a Harris presidency. Harris, responding to the concern in the final stretch of the campaign, released her “Opportunity Agenda for Black Men.”
snippet: White and Black women have joined together to power progressive causes — from abolition to civil rights — but it’s a tenuous alliance.

headline: A Tight Senate Battle Comes Down to a Few Key Races
abstract: Republicans are in good position to win the Senate majority, but Democrats still hold hope of retaining control.
lead_paragraph: After two years and a multibillion-dollar barrage of political attack ads, the fight for Senate control is down to a handful of races, with Republicans holding a clear edge but Democrats maintaining a narrow path to retaining their majority if events break their way.
snippet: Republicans are in good position to win the Senate majority, but Democrats still hold hope of retaining control.

headline: Harris’s Hope: Getting Right-Leaning Voters to Shift to the Left
abstract: Democrats see a narrow opening to peel away center-right voters bothered by abortion bans and by the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: For months, Gretchen Wolfe of Phoenix has agonized over her choices in this year’s presidential election.
snippet: Democrats see a narrow opening to peel away center-right voters bothered by abortion bans and by the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: Just How Online Was This Election?
abstract: In the 2024 presidential race, both nominees exploited a porous boundary between the internet and real life. Some viral moments, however, were out of their control.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps more so than in any presidential election that has come before it, the contest between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump has unfolded online.
snippet: In the 2024 presidential race, both nominees exploited a porous boundary between the internet and real life. Some viral moments, however, were out of their control.

headline: Would You Wear 200 Stuffed Animals?
abstract: Le Rêve Nazam’s teddy bear jeans are the surprising internet fashion hit of the year.
lead_paragraph: Some fashion designers use cotton. Others wool. Chad Nazam uses stuffed animals.
snippet: Le Rêve Nazam’s teddy bear jeans are the surprising internet fashion hit of the year.

headline: Trump, Preparing to Challenge the Results, Puts His 2020 Playbook Into Action
abstract: Step by step, Donald J. Trump and his allies are following the strategies that caused chaos four years ago. Election officials say they are ready this time.
lead_paragraph: Election 2024 live updates: Follow our coverage of Trump and Harris on Election Day.
snippet: Step by step, Donald J. Trump and his allies are following the strategies that caused chaos four years ago. Election officials say they are ready this time.

headline: Israel’s Peace Talks in Gaza and Lebanon: What to Know
abstract: Complex negotiations involving several players are proceeding on two separate but related tracks.
lead_paragraph: Cease-fire talks are underway to resolve two related conflicts in the Middle East that have killed tens of thousands of people and threaten to spiral into a wider regional war.
snippet: Complex negotiations involving several players are proceeding on two separate but related tracks.

headline: How a Trump Win Would Upend Major Climate Court Fights
abstract: A second Trump administration could stop defending the E.P.A. against lawsuits attacking its climate policies. Other effects might be more far-reaching.
lead_paragraph: A second Trump presidency would lead to a sea change for climate-related lawsuits in the nation’s courts.
snippet: A second Trump administration could stop defending the E.P.A. against lawsuits attacking its climate policies. Other effects might be more far-reaching.

headline: Exhale Through the Gift Shop
abstract: Museums are adding scents as another tool for communicating information about science and other subjects in their exhibits.
lead_paragraph: Does dark matter smell like pepper? Just how stinky was the breath of Tyrannosaurus rex? What was the fragrance of an extinct flower? And what scents might greet us on the moon or Mars?
snippet: Museums are adding scents as another tool for communicating information about science and other subjects in their exhibits.

headline: Trump Is Betting Big on Musk’s Swing-State Moonshot
abstract: The candidate is leaning on an unusual canvassing effort funded by Elon Musk. If successful, it could usher in a new era when billionaires dominate ground campaigns.
lead_paragraph: One morning in mid-April, Elon Musk sat in a suite at the Proper Hotel in downtown Austin and texted former President Donald J. Trump.
snippet: The candidate is leaning on an unusual canvassing effort funded by Elon Musk. If successful, it could usher in a new era when billionaires dominate ground campaigns.

headline: A Daughter of Immigrants Adopts a Tough Border Message in a Close House Race
abstract: Representative Yadira Caraveo of Colorado, whose parents entered the country illegally from Mexico, has become one of several Democrats to pivot to a pro-enforcement message.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Yadira Caraveo, Democrat of Colorado, addressed a largely Latino crowd this week at an event to celebrate the Day of the Dead, she came with a message of compassion and solidarity with immigrants.
snippet: Representative Yadira Caraveo of Colorado, whose parents entered the country illegally from Mexico, has become one of several Democrats to pivot to a pro-enforcement message.

headline: Young African Voters Sour on the Parties That Ushered in Liberation
abstract: Political parties that have governed for decades since African countries overthrew colonial rulers are now being challenged by frustrated young voters.
lead_paragraph: The resounding defeat this past week of the only political party that has governed Botswana since it gained independence 58 years ago sent tremors across the African continent.
snippet: Political parties that have governed for decades since African countries overthrew colonial rulers are now being challenged by frustrated young voters.

headline: ‘Cesspools,’ ‘Hellholes’ and ‘Beautiful Places’: How Trump Describes the U.S.
abstract: See how Donald J. Trump’s penchant for criticism extends to a topic that’s usually sacrosanct for candidates — the cities and states in the nation he aims to lead.
lead_paragraph: See how Donald J. Trump’s penchant for criticism extends to a topic that’s usually sacrosanct for candidates — the cities and states in the nation he aims to lead.
snippet: See how Donald J. Trump’s penchant for criticism extends to a topic that’s usually sacrosanct for candidates — the cities and states in the nation he aims to lead.

headline: Why Are Democrats Having Such a Hard Time Beating Trump?
abstract: The national political environment just isn’t as conducive to a Harris victory as many might imagine.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens Tuesday, it’s fair to say this campaign has not gone as smoothly as Democrats expected.
snippet: The national political environment just isn’t as conducive to a Harris victory as many might imagine.

headline: A Way Out of Mexico’s Constitutional Crisis? One Idea for Compromise Emerges.
abstract: A lone voice on Mexico’s Supreme Court has proposed a way to ease the political tensions that have arisen over a judicial overhaul. But big obstacles could prevent any deal.
lead_paragraph: Bespectacled and soft-spoken, Juan Luis González Alcántara has devoted his life to the law, writing tomes on complex doctrines and teaching at a top law school before rising to become a justice on Mexico’s Supreme Court.
snippet: A lone voice on Mexico’s Supreme Court has proposed a way to ease the political tensions that have arisen over a judicial overhaul. But big obstacles could prevent any deal.

headline: Peter Singer Wants to Shatter Your Moral Complacency
abstract: The controversial philosopher discusses societal taboos, Thanksgiving turkeys and whether anyone is doing enough to make the world a better place.
lead_paragraph: I believe that most of us, in our own humble ways, try to make the world better. Maybe that means giving what we can to charity or helping out in our community. Maybe it means eating less meat or driving less often. It’s enough for each of us to do our own little part.
snippet: The controversial philosopher discusses societal taboos, Thanksgiving turkeys and whether anyone is doing enough to make the world a better place.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 511
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 3, 2024.

headline: Abortion Rights Issue Surfaces in Canada Before U.S. Election
abstract: The Canadian government proposed legislation this week to crack down on anti-abortion organizations that provide “dishonest counseling” to pregnant women.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau addressed the House of Commons this week regarding abortion rights, he also had a message for his daughter, who was seated in the gallery.
snippet: The Canadian government proposed legislation this week to crack down on anti-abortion organizations that provide “dishonest counseling” to pregnant women.

headline: Tailgating in Wisconsin With the Bros Trump Needs
abstract: Gender is a main dividing line in 2024. And young swing-state voters know it.
lead_paragraph: One phenomenon that’s been getting a lot of attention during this election is the growing gender gap among young people.
snippet: Gender is a main dividing line in 2024. And young swing-state voters know it.

headline: Taking Time
abstract: Daylight saving time ends tomorrow. How will you make use of the extra hour?
lead_paragraph: The midday sun in my apartment this time of year is like a searchlight, illuminating every windowpane streak and every mote of dust. It’s obnoxious, honestly, like a teacher’s pet showing off: “Look how bright and unsparing I can be,” the sun seems to taunt, “just before I decamp for the next four months.”
snippet: Daylight saving time ends tomorrow. How will you make use of the extra hour?

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Threatens Israel With ‘Crushing Response’ to Strikes
abstract: His comments came as the Pentagon said it would send additional fighter jets and destroyers to the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader on Saturday threatened “a crushing response” to Israeli strikes on his country, as the Pentagon said it would deploy additional resources to the region in the coming months.
snippet: His comments came as the Pentagon said it would send additional fighter jets and destroyers to the Middle East.

headline: The Cost of a Nuclear Arsenal
abstract: Responses to an article in the “At the Brink” series, raising doubts about a huge overhaul of U.S. nuclear capacity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
snippet: Responses to an article in the “At the Brink” series, raising doubts about a huge overhaul of U.S. nuclear capacity.

headline: Whatever Happens Next, Trump Has Already Won a Tragic Victory
abstract: This election has shown that Arab American and Muslim American lives are considered to be expendable.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I was in Dubai for a reporting trip and met a Palestinian American woman named Alaa’ Odeh at a dinner party. She is from North Carolina but lives in Dubai, where she works as a strategy and public policy consultant. She had spoken passionately about her efforts to raise money to support people struggling to survive in Gaza, where she has mentored young Palestinians over the past decade. As I was leaving the dinner, we exchanged details and promised to keep in touch. As often happens when Americans meet abroad these days, we talked about the U.S. election, unfolding as the war in Gaza spreads to Lebanon.
snippet: This election has shown that Arab American and Muslim American lives are considered to be expendable.

headline: All the Demons Are Here
abstract: Trump goes out on a low note — not surprisingly.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the furor over Bill Clinton’s affair with Monica Lewinsky and his manipulative attempts to cover it up and figure out if he should lie about it or come clean, liberals began advancing the argument that the private character of a president should be differentiated from his public character.
snippet: Trump goes out on a low note — not surprisingly.

headline: I’ve Covered Authoritarians Abroad. Now I Fear One at Home.
abstract: But if Trump thinks his threats to cancel TV licenses or his crass warnings of jailing and prison rape will intimidate journalists, he’s wrong.
lead_paragraph: With this presidential election seemingly a jump ball, what might American democracy and the world look like if Donald Trump is again elected president?
snippet: But if Trump thinks his threats to cancel TV licenses or his crass warnings of jailing and prison rape will intimidate journalists, he’s wrong.

headline: If the Choice in 2024 Were So Obvious, the Election Wouldn’t Be So Close
abstract: Why opposing Trump is not so completely obvious, obligatory or a matter of simple common sense.
lead_paragraph: There are many styles of Harris-Walz signage in my lovely university-town neighborhood, but the one that’s stickiest in my mind comes with a one-word slogan: “Harris-Walz 2024: Obviously.”
snippet: Why opposing Trump is not so completely obvious, obligatory or a matter of simple common sense.

headline: Thank Goodness for the New York City Marathon
abstract: The marathon is glorious in part because it represents an ideal of civic life: people striving to accomplish their goals while seeking connection with others.
lead_paragraph: New York City Marathon weekend is here. You can feel the excitement throughout the city as runners flood in from around the world and move around in flocks with their running jackets and sneakers, speaking a multitude of languages.
snippet: The marathon is glorious in part because it represents an ideal of civic life: people striving to accomplish their goals while seeking connection with others.

headline: Springsteen Is Fighting Back the Darkness at the Edge of America
abstract: His music offers a model of how we all might just get through this.
lead_paragraph: A few days before the opening of the Democratic National Convention, I flew to Pittsburgh for the opening concert of the last American leg of Bruce Springsteen’s 2024 world tour. I have been to more than a hundred of his concerts in my life, but I wanted to see this performance in a city and state that could determine the outcome of the presidential election.
snippet: His music offers a model of how we all might just get through this.

headline: Humorless Feminists Against Trump
abstract: The former president does not value or respect women — and it shows in his words and his policies
lead_paragraph: Much of the outrage about Trump’s Madison Square Garden rally has been focused on the comments made by Tony Hinchcliffe, a comedian, about Puerto Rico (“a floating island of garbage”) and Black people (who “carved watermelons”). Hinchcliffe has defended himself by saying these were just jokes taken out of context. Trump’s running mate JD Vance claimed to have not seen the humor in them, but said, “I think that we have to stop getting so offended at every little thing in the United States of America. I’m just — I’m so over it.”
snippet: The former president does not value or respect women — and it shows in his words and his policies

headline: Vote to End the Trump Era
abstract: America should demand better.
lead_paragraph: America should demand better.
snippet: America should demand better.

headline: Amid Flood Cleanup in Spain, Residents Try to Make Sense of the Disaster
abstract: Some see the floods as an example of the effect of a changing climate that is making overwhelming downpours more common. Locals also say government warnings came too late.
lead_paragraph: Mari Luz Sánchez’s body lay on top of an overturned refrigerator in a corner of her kitchen when her family found her. A wave of water in the village of Chiva, in southeastern Spain, had deposited her there after devastating flooding across the region on Tuesday night.
snippet: Some see the floods as an example of the effect of a changing climate that is making overwhelming downpours more common. Locals also say government warnings came too late.

headline: Kemi Badenoch Becomes First Black Woman to Lead Britain’s Conservative Party
abstract: Ms. Badenoch is expected to move the party, now in the opposition, further to the right.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Conservative Party announced on Saturday that it had selected Kemi Badenoch as its leader, putting a charismatic, often combative, right-wing firebrand at the helm of a party that suffered a crushing election defeat in July.
snippet: Ms. Badenoch is expected to move the party, now in the opposition, further to the right.

headline: 2 Books to Take Your Mind Off Certain Current Events
abstract: An underground party memoir; an argument for nonhuman life.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,
snippet: An underground party memoir; an argument for nonhuman life.

headline: Fears of Civil Unrest Stalk the Markets
abstract: Wall Street advisers say investors are increasingly anxious about the possibility of election-related violence.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street strategists say their meetings with portfolio managers have taken a dark turn lately. All but gone are investors’ fears of a hard landing, replaced by a deeper anxiety that things could go very badly around Election Day.
snippet: Wall Street advisers say investors are increasingly anxious about the possibility of election-related violence.

headline: In Politics, Pro Athletes (and Owners) Are Just Like the Rest of Us: Divided
abstract: A pro-Harris video from LeBron James. A pro-Trump hat on Nick Bosa. With Election Day near, more have been showing their preference.
lead_paragraph: Over the past eight years, the three top American sports leagues — the National Basketball Association, Major League Baseball and the National Football League — have at times dived headlong into political maelstroms.
snippet: A pro-Harris video from LeBron James. A pro-Trump hat on Nick Bosa. With Election Day near, more have been showing their preference.

headline: Photographing Every President Since Reagan
abstract: Doug Mills reflects on nearly 40 years of taking photos of presidents.
lead_paragraph: Through his camera lens, Doug Mills has seen it all: George H.W. Bush playing horseshoes. An emotional Barack Obama. A shirtless Bill Clinton. And he’s shared what he’s seen with the world.
snippet: Doug Mills reflects on nearly 40 years of taking photos of presidents.

headline: Global Summit on Nature Adopts a Novel Way to Pay for Conservation
abstract: Delegates at the U.N. talks created a system that would compensate countries for the use of genetic information but failed to make headway on a broader funding commitment.
lead_paragraph: Diplomats from roughly 180 countries ended two weeks of environmental talks on Saturday after agreeing on a new fund that would shift some of the profits from nature’s DNA to global conservation efforts.
snippet: Delegates at the U.N. talks created a system that would compensate countries for the use of genetic information but failed to make headway on a broader funding commitment.

headline: Split on Economic Policy Puts Germany’s Government at Risk of Collapse
abstract: A breakup of the divided and unpopular coalition well before elections set for next September could leave the country directionless at a critical time for Europe.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s three-party coalition government, wracked by infighting and policy paralysis over a stagnant economy, is teetering on the brink of collapse.
snippet: A breakup of the divided and unpopular coalition well before elections set for next September could leave the country directionless at a critical time for Europe.

headline: Giant! Jam! Bun!
abstract: What’s better than a Melissa Clark scone? A Melissa Clark scone that’s supersize, swirled with jam, lightly glazed and showered with citrus zest.
lead_paragraph: I like my baked goods the same way I like my winter coats: positively giant. I want them oversize in a way that invites you to snuggle into them, buttoning up the exterior so that you’re fully encased in sweet warmth.
snippet: What’s better than a Melissa Clark scone? A Melissa Clark scone that’s supersize, swirled with jam, lightly glazed and showered with citrus zest.

headline: Richard A. Cash, Who Saved Millions From Dehydration, Dies at 83
abstract: He worked alongside another doctor to show that a simple rehydration therapy could check the ravages of cholera and other diarrhea-inducing diseases.
lead_paragraph: Richard A. Cash, who as a young public-health researcher in South Asia in the late 1960s showed that a simple cocktail of salt, sugar and clean water could check the ravages of cholera and other diarrhea-inducing diseases, an innovation that has saved an estimated 50 million lives, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 83.
snippet: He worked alongside another doctor to show that a simple rehydration therapy could check the ravages of cholera and other diarrhea-inducing diseases.

headline: What a Trump Rally Showed Me That Videos Never Could
abstract: At Donald J. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, a Times reporter saw a more complete picture of the people who fuel his political movement.
lead_paragraph: I emerged from the subway last Sunday into what seemed like a wall of people. Their chatter, shouts and laughter filled the morning air. Some had dressed in suits and ties; others wore jeans and sweatshirts. They sported patriotically sequined hats, American flags draped over their shoulders like capes and the red baseball caps that have symbolized Donald J. Trump’s political movement for nearly a decade.
snippet: At Donald J. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, a Times reporter saw a more complete picture of the people who fuel his political movement.

headline: Will Democracy Ever Not Be on the Ballot?
abstract: It is on Tuesday. It was four years ago — and eight years ago, too.
lead_paragraph: To conclude my Friday column on the stakes of the 2024 presidential election, I quoted a passage from Sean Wilentz’s 2005 book on the rise of American democracy. Here’s the passage, which I want to quote again because it’s a great piece of prose and directly relevant to an observation I want to make.
snippet: It is on Tuesday. It was four years ago — and eight years ago, too.

headline: Trump’s Microphone Trouble in Milwaukee Leaves Him ‘Seething’
abstract: After rally goers complained that they could not hear him, the former president asked, “Do you want to see me knock the hell out of people backstage?”
lead_paragraph: Election 2024 live updates: Follow our coverage of Trump and Harris on Election Day.
snippet: After rally goers complained that they could not hear him, the former president asked, “Do you want to see me knock the hell out of people backstage?”

headline: Biden Left the Presidential Race, but His Legacy Depends on It
abstract: The Trump campaign has taken aim at many of President Biden’s signature legislative achievements.
lead_paragraph: President Biden may not be on the ballot next week, but his legacy is riding on the outcome of the election.
snippet: The Trump campaign has taken aim at many of President Biden’s signature legislative achievements.

headline: Patricia Johanson, Who Turned Grim Outdoor Spaces Into Art, Dies at 84
abstract: A groundbreaking environmental artist, she transformed water treatment plants and fetid ponds into enticing natural artworks.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Johanson, an environmental artist who made nature her medium, transforming highway underpasses, sewage treatment plants and other grimly functional public spaces into sweeping artworks, died on Oct. 16 at her home in Buskirk, N.Y., northeast of Albany. She was 84.
snippet: A groundbreaking environmental artist, she transformed water treatment plants and fetid ponds into enticing natural artworks.

headline: Janey Godley, 63, Dies; Comedian Brought Humor to Harrowing Topics
abstract: A Scottish performer, she said she believed there were “funny sides” to terrible experiences, including some that she drew from her own times of loss and hardship.
lead_paragraph: Janey Godley, a Scottish comedian, actor and writer whose hard-hitting, candid wit established her as a comedy star and who became widely known for her parody voice-overs of elected leaders during the coronavirus pandemic, died on Saturday in Glasgow. She was 63.
snippet: A Scottish performer, she said she believed there were “funny sides” to terrible experiences, including some that she drew from her own times of loss and hardship.

headline: Investigation of MrBeast’s Company Finds No Evidence of Sexual Misconduct
abstract: An independent law firm led the investigation after allegations of sexual misconduct surfaced against Ava Tyson, a collaborator with the YouTube star MrBeast.
lead_paragraph: A law firm that investigated accusations of sexual misconduct and grooming within the organization of the YouTube star MrBeast said on Friday that it found no evidence to support those claims.
snippet: An independent law firm led the investigation after allegations of sexual misconduct surfaced against Ava Tyson, a collaborator with the YouTube star MrBeast.

headline: Israel Says Elite Naval Commandos Abducted Hezbollah Operative
abstract: It appeared to be the deepest Israeli operation by sea and ground inside Lebanon during the current war.
lead_paragraph: Israeli naval commandos, ferried by speedboats, captured a man Israel called a senior Hezbollah operative in a sea-and-land operation on Friday that marked the deepest known incursion yet by Israeli forces into Lebanese territory during this war.
snippet: It appeared to be the deepest Israeli operation by sea and ground inside Lebanon during the current war.

headline: When Your Dating Pool Includes Elves and Mages
abstract: Dragon Age: The Veilguard is the latest video game to lean into relationships between fellow adventurers that grow into something more.
lead_paragraph: Boy meets girl. Boy wants to talk to girl but isn’t sure how. It’s an age-old problem, but one that isn’t an issue in Dragon Age: The Veilguard, a new video game in which a dialogue option can lead to love if it is marked with a big ol’ heart.
snippet: Dragon Age: The Veilguard is the latest video game to lean into relationships between fellow adventurers that grow into something more.

headline: Adams Issues Drought Watch for New York City as Dry Weather Persists
abstract: The measure, announced by the mayor on Saturday, does not impose restrictions on New Yorkers, but officials are urging residents to use less water.
lead_paragraph: Many New Yorkers have reason to be pleased with their luck this fall. They were able to experience Central Park’s vibrant October foliage under clear skies and go trick-or-treating on an unseasonably warm Halloween. And the sunny weather is expected to continue Sunday as runners take to the streets for the New York City Marathon.
snippet: The measure, announced by the mayor on Saturday, does not impose restrictions on New Yorkers, but officials are urging residents to use less water.

headline: Trump and Harris Offer Night-and-Day Views of the Economy
abstract: The candidates outlined vastly different messages in Georgia, North Carolina and Virginia, with Donald J. Trump exaggerating how bad the recent jobs report was and Kamala Harris promising to bring down costs.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump swept through Southern states on Saturday, outlining sharply divergent economic messages for voters in top battlegrounds and, in Mr. Trump’s case, solidly blue Virginia.
snippet: The candidates outlined vastly different messages in Georgia, North Carolina and Virginia, with Donald J. Trump exaggerating how bad the recent jobs report was and Kamala Harris promising to bring down costs.

headline: Dub Jones, Who Scored 6 Touchdowns for Browns in One Game, Dies at 99
abstract: A 6-foot-4 halfback and flanker, he was a tall, reliable target for Browns quarterback Otto Graham as Cleveland rolled to titles in the late 1940s and ’50s.
lead_paragraph: Dub Jones, an All-Pro running back and flanker for Cleveland Browns championship teams of the late 1940s and ’50s and one of four N.F.L. players to score six touchdowns in a single game, died on Saturday at his home in Ruston, La. He was 99.
snippet: A 6-foot-4 halfback and flanker, he was a tall, reliable target for Browns quarterback Otto Graham as Cleveland rolled to titles in the late 1940s and ’50s.

headline: What to Know About the Electoral College
abstract: “This is a very unique and bespoke system that I think nobody would create again today,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: Voters are already casting ballots for local offices, state legislators, governors, every member of the U.S. House and one-third of the U.S. Senate as Election Day nears.
snippet: “This is a very unique and bespoke system that I think nobody would create again today,” one expert said.

headline: 6th Tennessee Factory Worker Is Found a Month After Flooding From Helene
abstract: She is believed to be the last employee who was missing after the plastics plant flooded. Authorities are still investigating the circumstances around the deaths.
lead_paragraph: The remains of a sixth factory worker in eastern Tennessee who was swept away in the flooding brought on by Hurricane Helene have been found, ending a search for what is believed to be the last missing employee more than a month after the storm tore through the Southeast.
snippet: She is believed to be the last employee who was missing after the plastics plant flooded. Authorities are still investigating the circumstances around the deaths.

headline: James Ledbetter, Media Critic and Business Journalist, Dies at 60
abstract: He wrote the Press Clips column for The Village Voice, held top jobs at Inc. magazine and Slate, and wrote a book about how the startup magazine The Industry Standard fizzled.
lead_paragraph: James Ledbetter, a former media critic who wrote the Press Clips column for The Village Voice in the 1990s, led Inc. magazine as its editor in chief and started an online financial technology newsletter, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60.
snippet: He wrote the Press Clips column for The Village Voice, held top jobs at Inc. magazine and Slate, and wrote a book about how the startup magazine The Industry Standard fizzled.

headline: Can I Have a Raise?
abstract: Share Sid Sivakumar’s Sunday puzzle with management.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
snippet: Share Sid Sivakumar’s Sunday puzzle with management.

headline: Biden Returns to His Home Turf to Make Final Pitches for Harris
abstract: Though President Biden has made verbal gaffes on the campaign trail, the Harris campaign still considers him an asset in blue-collar communities like Scranton, Pa.
lead_paragraph: In Scranton, Pa., it’s as though President Biden never left.
snippet: Though President Biden has made verbal gaffes on the campaign trail, the Harris campaign still considers him an asset in blue-collar communities like Scranton, Pa.

headline: TGI Fridays, the Casual Dining Chain, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Saturday but said its restaurants would remain open while it works on a “restructuring process.”
lead_paragraph: TGI Fridays Inc., the casual American dining chain that for more than half a century served customers happy-hour deals, hamburgers and comfort-food appetizers like mozzarella sticks and loaded potato skins, filed for bankruptcy protection on Saturday.
snippet: The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Saturday but said its restaurants would remain open while it works on a “restructuring process.”
